content: I've just fixed Validator 2 and removed the trailing newline in the input after getting a report on that issue on the forum: https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-decimal-numbers-to-floating-numbers-puzzle-discussion/203265/15

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting and fun, why not.

Hi,

I think you should double some test/validator, for example "Simple decimal" which are the first with an "+" or "-", the "+" is only a test and the "-" is only a validator, it could be both.
You don't check much for the "Invalid numbers", maybe some invalid in scientific notation, some invalid because it starts with another character than "+" or "-", ...
You don't have any test with scientific notation with an integer and a negative exponent, only a validator "255e-2"

This is really cool. So much work have been put into this, even someone like me can understand it. Well Done!

Unfortunately this is not my strongest subject, so I will leave it up to others to approve.

It's an interesting puzzle, but since you're using the same standard as programming languages, you can cheat by using [no no no, I won't help anyone to cheat ;) ]. The following C++ solution works for every tests and validators !

[code removed]

You can avoid this by asking for something other than the IEEE754 standard. For example, one bit more for the exponent and one less for the mantissa.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun but not trivial, useful to understand concepts that we take for granted

I have a doubt about this part:
We then reformat our previous results:
(b10) 15.5 = (b2) 1111.1 = (b2) 1.1111 * 2^-3
(b10) 0.125 = (b2) 0.001 = (b2) 1 * 2^3
I think 
(b10) 15.5=(b2) 1.1111*2^3 (not -3)
(b10) 0.125=(b2) 1*2^-3 (not 3). 
where am I wrong? Thanks

Interesting and well described problem. I wonder if, for NaN, it wasn't useful to use a standard instead of setting e to FF...
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NaN

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good exercise. I love it !!

I like the idea in the puzzle, but I'm not sure it is relevant have NaNs, it seems off the point of the puzzle, but more importantly, using a coma as separator is normal to some people so that can be confusing, try maybe a string ?
More importantly, I don't think that is medium. Is it really ?
Thanks for your comment. I updated with suggested points.

Goal
* I haven't read the statement in detail yet, but it seems that you may want to apply `monospace formatting` in the explanation of "We need to truncate at 23 bits"?

* Please format s, e and m as [[variables]].

Output
* Please change "[s][e][m]" to "{{[}}[[s]]{{][}}[[e]]{{][}}[[m]]{{]}}".

* Please change "output" to something specific (maybe "general format")?

Input
* Please add "which may or may not be expressed in scientific notation (such as {{5.63e15}})".

Constraints
* Please delete the second constraint.

Thanks.

I had no notification/idea that you had updated because you started a new comment instead of replying to my comment ðŸ˜…

I have a detailed read just now. Below are the comments based on the updated version:

Goal
* Please change "that we note b10" to "denoted b10".

* Suggest to change "base 2 (b2)" to "base 2 (denoted b2)".

* Suggest to change "two different parts" to "two parts".

* For the fractional part:

   â€¢ Step 2: Suggest to change "go to 3" to "go to Step 3".
   
   â€¢ Step 2: Suggest to change "restart at 1" to "restart at Step 1" (twice).
   
   â€¢Â Step 2: Please change ">=" to "â‰¥".

* Please move the whole line "Example: 15.5: (etc)" to just above "Example with 0.5:", so that the explanation is grouped together and the example of 15.5 is not split apart.

* Example with 0.5:

   â€¢ Suggest to delete "Example with 0.5:" after the above regrouping of text.

   â€¢ Suggest to add "and get 0 (1-1) for the next round" after "subtract 1".

   â€¢ After the above is done, "0 (1-1)" may be changed to "0".

* Example with 0.125: Suggest to change "[0]" and "[1]" to "[store 0]" and "[store 1]" respectively.

* (1.xxxxx) * 2^exp: Please format "exp" as "[[exp]]".

* 127-exp: Please format "exp" as "[[exp]]".

* mantissa rule: Please change "decimal points" to "decimal point".

* mantissa rule: Please change "less then" to "less than".

* Example of 1.1: Please change "more then" to "more than".

* Next bit is 1 rule: Please change "et" to "and".

Input
* Please rewrite as follows:

A string [[N]] which may or may not be a valid decimal number. It may have a prefix of {{+}} or {{-}} to indicate its sign, and it may be expressed in scientific notation (such as {{5.63e15}}, {{3.14e+5}}).

Cover picture
* Suggest to upload a cover picture for the puzzle.

Thanks.

Your comment makes sense and I am changing the validation. Well, let's say that NaN is the default approach to manage any parsing issue... 

Now, on the difficulty itself indeed I was hesitating, not much used to define it.
You are totally right ! It does not make sense at all to use FFFFFF for a binary value... I did not see it, my bad. So, thanks a lot, I correct it immediately,
You are not ! This is the text which is not in sync with the code and the standard... Many thanks,

If you don't understand [code removed] (not easy if you're not familiar with pointers), this is an equivalent :

[code removed]

(no worry totally familiar with pointers ;) )

Regarding the possibility to cheat, you are totally right and I though about the same from the beginning. At the same time, I was wondering if it makes sense to fake the standard where the purpose is to understand how it works. But the point is valid... so, still wondering what is the best approach.
Ok, I just wanted to be sure you knew the problem. I won't ask you to modifiy your solution or any test case since your worked well on your puzzle.

Thanks for your comments, it helps a lot to be much clearer.

I applied them but I cannot expand more on some details as I reached to max number of characters.... So, I decided to remove the details of the second example with 0.125 which finally is quite simple.

I will add soon a cover picture.

OK, thank you for the changes! Below are the comments based on the revised version:

Goal
* Please delete "Example: 15.5: the whole part = 15, the fractional part = .5 (if we include the decimal point).".

* Please delete "(b10) 15 => (b2) 1111".

* Above the line "Fractional part: 0.5", please add:

Example: 15.5: the whole part = 15, the fractional part = .5 (if we include the decimal point).

Whole part: 15
(b10) 15 => (b2) 1111

(As mentioned in my last comment, the above changes are done so that the explanation is not split apart, and the example is not split apart either.)

Cover picture
* Pending.

Thanks again.
Thanks again for your help. We should be good now.

Please fix the issues reported on the forum by java_coffee_cup and nicola.

I think you can fix both of them at the same time by changing "Scientific notation (4)" test to have a negative number in scientific notation.

Thanks.
